title: What are the maxims of Kant's philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Kantian maxim of action is the basis for actions. This gives a basis for ethics as explained by Kant. Then comes the categorical imperative. Example: I will do exercise everyday to be healthy.“doing exercise” is the action and the end result is “being healthy” in the above statement. These maxims can generalize to apply at a larger scope. When the subjective principle of maxim made objective it becomes a law. An interesting valid maxim by Kant about his smoking only one pipe a day and later buying a larger pipe is a puzzle. Read more at: http://www.harvardphilosophy.com/issues/2000/Timmermann.pdf More on Categorical imperative from one of my earlier answers on Quora: Prasad Chitta's answer to What are some examples of modern day categorical imperative? Hope this helps in forming your own “maxims”

Kant said to make decisions as if each decision would become a general rule for mankind. I think he was trying to find a non-religious alternative for the Golden Rule, a philosophical rule that people could live by. He called in the Categorical Imperative. But I think Kant’s work was a failure. It is mostly too complicated for people to understand and it is in the end wrong - that he tried to think about thinking using logic alone but his categories and terminology do not match up with modern neuroscience. So, good try, but a failure. Studying Kant is a waste of time. It is an intellectual exercise that leads no where. Kant’s most know work, The Critique of Pure Reason was based on a class he had taught for 30 years. But the book was written hastily in a few months. The writing is obscure, so people think Kant is smart.
